Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Drs. Tucker and Grim have an expansive and encyclopaedic knowledge of the religions of the worlds, but are still open to learning new things and open to new perceptions. This course included a trip to the Beinecke library for a viewing of Rachel Carson's original papers, which gave specific insights and created connections to the readings and in-class discussions. Excellent professors, important material, and a terrifically crafted course that integrates cross-discipline topics in one package. I would recommend this course to others.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Best part of this class was combining two disciplines that usually don't seem to go together. It was helpful and insightful to learn from other students not in FES and have great discussions on the topics we learned in class.
Good discussion rounds. Extraordinarily friendly professors. Open atmosphere.

The discussion time! I really appreciated having all of the class time be about productive discussion. Having a couple of students come prepared each week with questions was useful too (although this could have been explained a little clearer to avoid lots of rambling and summary by students). I also thought there was pretty good balance between reading and videos/lectures. I'm much more of a visual/reading learner than an audio learner so have appropriate reading material is essential for me in an online course like this.
I really liked the online discussions, they were so open and students reflected on the materials in a very personal way which made the discussions even more interesting.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I know there are a lot of items to grade with so many students in the course, however it would be helpful if we got more timely feedback on the weekly assignments. If we don't get grades and feedback until after the course is over, there's no opportunity to improve as the course goes on.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I am interested in ecology and conservation. To learn how religious (non-scientists) view nature and understand them, helps in trying to collaborate in the future for aid in conservation efforts.

The science and policy of the FES program, with the necessary infusion of a transcendent and essential part of equation; the binding and over-arching "force" of religion. Understanding the base values and motivations that people derive from their religions is necessary to gaining perspective about how and why they do what they do when it comes to the environment.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: It's a completely new subject area for me and thought this would be a fascinating new view on environmental issues through the lens of religion.
personal interest

I am very interested in the relationship between religion and ecology, and environmental issues as a whole. I thought this course would give a great overview on this topic and it definitely fulfilled my expectations.
To gain a broader perspective of how the religions of the world view the environment in their traditional teachings and contemporary application.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes. I got a good, broad introduction to the world religions and how different interpretations can impart different relationships with nature and the environment.

Yes, they did. I was able to go as deep into the material as I wanted to because of the flipped format. The inclass and online discussions both provided forums for sharing viewpoints and freely exchanging ideas. The online portion was particularly important for this, allowing classmates to add to the discussion at their convenience.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take this course. The professors are really good.
Be willing to explore different points of view. From your classmate and from the people who are representing or elaborating on different religious views.
This course is great, it gives a great overview of the role of religion in environmental issues. Would definitely recommend, and as a 6-week course it goes by very fast, maybe too fast!

In the 6 week course, the material is clearly structured and you can be as involved as you would like to be. Both professors are very open to questions and comments and do a great job of not just telling you information, but leading you to your own understanding.
